article.title: An admissible level $\widehat {\mathfrak {osp}} \left ( 1 \middle \vert 2 \right )$-model: modular transformations and the Verlinde formula

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 depicts the submodule inclusions for two Verma modules at level k=-5/4. What do the pairs (λ, Δ) attached to each vertex represent?
choices: The weight and conformal weight of a highest-weight vector in the submodule
The weight and conformal weight of a singular vector generating a Verma submodule
The eigenvalue of the super-Casimir Σ and the conformal weight of the corresponding singular vector
The level and central charge of the corresponding Verma module

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (3.15) defines the admissible levels for the affine Kac-Moody superalgebra osp(1|2). What condition must the parameter "t" satisfy for a level to be admissible?
choices: t must be a non-negative integer
t must be a positive rational number, expressed as u/v where u and v are coprime integers with specific parity conditions
t must be an eigenvalue of the super-Casimir operator Σ
t must be equal to the central charge of the corresponding minimal model

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (5.28) expresses the character of the atypical standard B0|1(2,4)-modules C±±1/2. What does this formula tell us about the dependence of the character on the variables "z" and "q"?
choices: The character is a holomorphic function of both "z" and "q"
The character depends on "z" and "q" only through the product "zq"
The character is a product of a function depending only on "z" and a function depending only on "q"
The character is a Laurent series in "z" whose coefficients are meromorphic functions of "q"

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (7.6b) presents the standard Verlinde formula for calculating the Verlinde coefficients of the B0|1(2,4)-module. What does the integral in this formula represent?
choices: The sum of the S-matrix entries connecting the modules M, N, and P
The product of the S-matrix entries connecting the modules M, N, and P to a common standard module Q, summed over all Q in a specific set
The trace of the modular S-transformation acting on the (super)character of the fusion product M x N
The integral of the product of the characters of the modules M, N, and P over the modular parameter τ
